title: I feel like Boards is very supportive of "new playstyles"....until one actually appears.
body:
Viktor is a great example because this happened twice now.

Early on in the season, Viktor started taking Fleet Footwork. It let him do some cool trading patterns and survive lane, enabling him to exist when he wasn't in the best state. Sounds cool right? VIktor taking a keystone that isn't obvious and finding success....nope. According to a forum post, this was to show "how dire the state of Viktor was" that he had to take fleet footwork to survive. 

We're now seeing it again with Klepto viktor. A response to Urgot/Aatrox/etc. and other slow moving but strong champions where Viktor can poke and harass. A meta adaption to a common strategy? Countering the current "OP" picks with an unexpected and unique playstyle? Boards should be **LOVING** this! _Nope_. This is a "cancer playstyle" that "isn't fun to play against" and should be reworked or removed.

Every time I see something weird or unique come out, it's not a cool adaption to the state of the game. It's not  an evolution to playing a champion and a viable alternative. It's written off as "unfun", "not how the champ should be played" or "garbage". Taliyah becoming a jungler isn't a weird a cool new evolution of the character, it's Riot killing Taliyah and the only way she can survive is in the jungle? Even if she's still got some power in the midlane? (According to OP.gg, she's sitting at a 51% winrate and a 14% pick rate. Really killed her midlane, eh?)

For a community that looks back on the glory days of going AP Tristana, On-hit GP and more, you guys sure are quick to demand Riot remove a new playstyle whenever it appears. Who deems what is "a viable playstyle" and what is "a bulshit adaption"? Why is it that a champion going a rune-or-mastery path they don't usually go become a sign of how far that champ has fallen? Why can't we accept that maybe this champ finding success with this set-up _isn't_ a sign of the champ being in dire straits but a sign that the champ can find success with a new way of thinking?

EDIT: To add an important comment from below that I made.

>Again: The problem isn't "I think Viktor should get some nerfs", the problem is that apparently people would rather see a new and emerging build completely and utterly removed rather than balanced to accommodate a new playstyle. People don't want Viktor top to be a thing you can pocket pick, they want it removed because Viktor should ONLY BE AN AP MIDLANER AND ANYTHING ELSE IS AGAINST THE GOSPEL. Still, Viktor is but one example.

replies.body: Maybe it's because we enjoy the idea that champions should either be strong in one role, or medium in multiple roles. Maybe it's because we like tank/fighter/assassin toplanes and find that mage and marksman toplane fights are straight up awful. Maybe it's because Riot should keep champions strong in the roles that they belong in, rather then shoving them off to other lanes, making balance even more difficult. It's one thing to be Jayce, or Graves, or Yasuo and be playable practically anywhere. It's quite another when a traditional midlane only champion gets moved into toplane because of Riot's ineffective balancing.

>Maybe it's because Riot should keep champions strong in the roles that they belong in, rather then shoving them off to other lanes, making balance even more difficult.

And who determines this?

What if Viktor's role _should_ be top lane? What if maybe Diana is better in the jungle than mid-lane? Basically, you're falling into the exact thing I pointed out: "I don't like this playstyle. Viktor should only be a midlaner." And apparently this _wasn't_ a balance issue, considering it wasn't found out for months, even years, after Viktor's rework. 

Again: The problem isn't "I think Viktor should get some nerfs", the problem is that apparently people would rather see a new and emerging build completely and utterly removed rather than balanced to accommodate a new playstyle. People don't want Viktor top to be a thing you can pocket pick, they want it removed because Viktor should ONLY BE AN AP MIDLANER AND ANYTHING ELSE IS AGAINST THE GOSPEL. Still, Viktor is but one example.

The only reason there the current reaction exists is because he is strong enough to maintain a 52% winrate and a 30+% pick+ban rate. If he had a 50% winrate and a 10% pick+ban rate, there wouldn't be nearly the same reaction.

>He hard counters too many champions which is why his winrate is so high despite having a few terrible matchups like you point out.

Like I mentioned in a previous post, people should start taking those counters then. If Viktor is strong to the point of instalock, people should begin looking for ways to play against it. I know, it's league blasphemy to consider that maybe I can't instalock my main every single game but if it's -really- that bad, people need to pick it. 

As boards often says, League should be about adapting your gameplay and skills rather than going the same cookie cutter path every game.....yet when presented with the choice of learn a new champ to deal with Viktor vs. "just do the same thing until Riot nerfs it", people will almost always pick the latter.

If this current version of Viktor took time and the playrate went up over time, then I would accept it and look at what can be picked into it. Having it just jump out of the woodwork and start smacking things left and right is just not the right thing (Anyone recall when the Banner meta forced itself in with one buff as the best playstyle, and it choked the everlasting shit out of innovation and skill?).

Hell, even with a 51% pickrate, Viktor's winrate is 51% as well. Counters and answers _do_ exist, it's about finding and adapting them.

A proper nerf shouldn't keep viktor in the top 40 champions that are always pick/banned, it should drop him to about the power of the 70th champion in the game (and this applies to every champion, not just viktor).

I'm not talking about champions who play on autopilot, but player mentality. They feel like they are entitled to build the same way and play the same way every game, and win every game, otherwise it's either the team being full of noobs and they can't "1v9" or the thing they were against is broken.
okay, but what about champions that "force" you to play in different ways?  it feels awful and disrupts the game while giving those champions artificial power

Well, not quite. Yes, they do get some artificial power, but a player that wants to climb and get better must be able to adapt and change his game plan, if he doesn't, he doesn't deserve to climb.

It can feel awful, especially for players who don't care about ranked and just want to play for fun in normals, but those are the least affected, while players in ranked should be able to adapt. 

Champions that are hard to defeat if you don't know how to do certain things are unfun to play against for a majority of players because they lose all agency. Wave management, power spikes, loss of power, positioning and others can make or break champions, and all those are "basic" knowledge, but when a champion forces the need of those aspects, making them mandatory instead of them being an advantage, it feels like you have no counter play, no agency unless you can do those things.

Some will call those champions cancer or unfun, but they are actually ok. We already see complaints how teammates are noobs in all ranks, champions like these make it so that those who climb have at least some basic knowledge.

They only disrupt the game if you only play on autopilot.

It's always been like that.
People like to talk how much they want diversity and dynamic builds and unique playstyles, but when one actually becomes viable they call it cancer because, jokes on them, when someone brings in a unique playstyle, the counter to it is way less obvious.

Just throw in "inting Sion" aswell, people complain about toplaners having no impact and how if you dont 1 shot someone you are useless, the comes this tanky slow guy who wins games by taking objectives, and people HATE it.

Honestly this discussion is an amusing read but it does show one of the most toxic things about League culture - blaming.  It's easy to blame a pick that's a good matchup rather than your ability to create advantages or to learn to try other champions.  Its easier to blame a teammate than it is to figure out how to improve.  And frankly this probably happens all over the place, ADCs have often been infamous for blaming sup/jg and plenty of ADC mains (myself included) blamed Riot for ruining the role when mages became optimal in bot during 8.11.

But holy shit, I don't think I've seen more blaming the game anywhere other than toplane this year.  Specifically these onetrick bruiser players who are constantly complaining about whatever ranged bully is currently popular while kissing the feet of Hashinshin.  It's understandable that its frustrating dealing with Gnar, Jayce, Ryze, Viktor, Quinn, w/e happens to be out there.  But these picks also get stomped by certain assassins, bruisers, mages, and tanks based on matchup.  There's plenty of flavors of melee champion.  But instead of adapting, we've got this culture that wants Riot to gut anything with range because that's easier than actually learning your matchup or another champion.

It's ok if you think the state of the game is better when there's more melee champions toplane, that's a fair opinion and most champions designed for the role are melee champions.  But we literally had double mage meta in S1 and there's always been a couple of floating ranged bullies in the toplane champion pool.  When dealing with melee vs ranged, melee typically gets more loaded abilities, more dashes, more power.  Meanwhile ranged has the power to kite, they always get the first shot, and if they position right they should be able to poke.  It's basically an explosive all in vs draining your opponent very generally, and while this often leans harder into one or the other I think the variety of champions available has created a healthy balance when the numbers are in a good spot... though I guess this state of the game that's been going on ever since League was live is suddenly unhealthy uninteractive garbage that should be deleted?

It's honestly disheartening how common this mindset is, but honestly Riot seems to know better than to act on whiny impulses... most of the time.  Though honestly even if Riot did listen to some of this, look at how many mages, marksman, and fighters with ranged abilities there are in the game.  Even if you keep gutting them there'll always be another one unless you delete half the champions and turn the game into "League of Melee".  And lets be real, at that point we're going to hear outcry about tanks because no one is poking them down.

I never had a problem with Viktor top, I see it as a hit or miss. If you hit you'll be relevant the rest of the game. Miss, and your damage will be non-existent and you'll have to catch up (or never catch up).
